Questions: Are you a fan of the work of Andre Norton? How were you introduced to her writing?
Answers:
Andre was a dear friend and co-writer, and is probably the reason why I am a writer today. I came across one of her books in the public library and was hooked forever. In the days before the internet and bookstores everywhere (the nearest was 50 miles away in Chicago) I saved up my money and mail-ordered her books from the ads in the backs of her books. I couldn’t afford to buy books as fast as I could read them, so I began writing what now is called “fanfiction” set in her worlds. I think I was probably every bit of 11 years old at the time.

Eventually I got to meet her and work with her. She was gracious and enthusiastic and never really believed how brilliant her writing was. I miss her every day.

Questions: How well-known is Roland Bartetzko's book in Kosovo? Does it barely sell or is it a hit?
Answers:
I can't complain.

When I published the Albanian language edition of my book in Kosovo, I called the biggest bookstore in the country and asked them if they wanted a few copies.

They said “okay, bring us some copies” and I went there with a big box containing sixty-five books. When they saw me they said, “oh, no! This is far too much, we've been thinking about two or three copies!”

My book was on a TV show last week which helped me to sell a lot of copies. (Photo: screenshot from a Facebook video)

Fortunately, the manager wasn’t there and I could lie to them that their boss had told me to deliver all these books. They shrugged and took the box.

This was on a Friday. The next Monday, they called me and said they needed more books.

Since then, the book[1]is constantly selling well. There were dozens of newspaper articles about it and I also had the privilege to present it on several TV shows.

Footnotes

[1] Amazon.com: The Smell of War: Lessons from the Battlefield eBook: Bartetzko, Roland, Kryeziu, Faton, Mustafa, Valbona, Tmava, Fiolla: Kindle Store

Questions: What was Mercedes Lackey's first book?
Answers: The first book I started writing was The Outstretched Shadow, but I quickly realized the book I wanted was way past my skill-set at that point. I dropped it and wrote short stories until I started Arrows of the Queen, which became my first published book.

Questions: What tiny, almost unnoticeable detail in a movie, book, or TV show do you love?
Answers:
Do you hate Twilight?

Probably yes.

But this little detail from New Moon never fails to impress me.

Remember how Bella spirals into around four months of depression after Edward leaves her?

The movie shows how the months pass, as Bella keeps sitting in the same position in a stillness like death.

Days, seasons, and people pass by.

But Bella just keeps staring out of the window, lonesome and lifeless.

Hmm, but did you notice something?

See how there are fewer and fewer pictures of her friends hung up on the wall, as each month passes by?

It symbolises her loneliness; how she gets detached from her friends, her family, how disconnected she is from her life now.

How her pain made her almost lifeless, and she just sits there, month after month, without a purpose, just drifting by.

The haunting track “Possibility” playing in the background just makes the scene all the rawer.

I don’t know about you, but for me, this scene has a special place in my heart, because of how perfectly it captures the intrinsic essence of depression and detachment in a hauntingly beautiful way.

Call it a bad movie, call Bella a weak character, a bad role model, but this scene?

It’s fucking real.

Questions: What interesting thing did you read today?
Answers:
A tribal came for a loan of Rs 2 lakhs to buy buffaloes & start selling milk.

Bank manager asked him for a collateral security.

The tribal asked what is collateral security?

Bank manager explained that bank needs equal amount of security in the form of an asset.

The tribal asked since the bank will be charging interest, then why collateral ?

Bank manager, a little pestered still kept explaining. The tribal agreed to keep his house as security. The formalities were completed and loan of Rs 2 lakhs was sanctioned at 9% interest repayable in 5 years.

After 6 months, the guy returned to pay off the entire bank loan amount.

Manager asked him how is his business to which he replied it's going on superb and he could amass good amount in short period.

Manager thought of his deposit target for march and asked what is he doing with the money earned. He replied that he kept it in his house in locked box.

Manager was so happy to hear that. He told the tribal that he can keep the money with the bank and bank will pay him interest.

Now the most interesting part that described the state of our banks….

The tribal asked “what collateral security will your bank give ??”.

Questions: Where does Robert Heinlein belong in the pantheon of science fiction writers?
Answers:
God sits at the right hand of Robert Anson Heinlein, and Spider Robinson is his prophet.

Heinlein did something that was rather new in sci-fi at the time. He wrote “contemporary” science fiction. That is, apart from the notable example of Starship Troopers, Heinlein for the most part did not bother to explain how everything worked. He assumed his readers were smart enough to either figure it out, or realize that the how didn’t matter so much as the what.

In Beyond this Horizon, Heinlein wrote “the door dilated” without ever explaining just what that meant. It didn’t matter. The door was closed, now it’s open, and clearly it opens by a different mechanism that we are accustomed to, but that doesn’t matter so much because the status of the door is more important than how it works.

This is because Heinlein was more interested in how new technologies or gadgets affected people, rather than how the gee-wiz gizmos worked themselves. Certainly he didn’t ignore technical details, he was an engineer. But he didn’t wag on about them for their sake alone. It always came back to how it affected the characters and plot. For example, in Starship Troopers he didn’t explain how radar, radio, or infrared snoopers worked, or even exactly how the “musculature” of the Maurauder suits worked, but he did describe the command and control systems of the Marauder suits. But even then, while he was clearly excited about how such a machine was controlled, the reason to explain the functioning was so that you could appreciate how easy it made for the person to operate the suit and maintain battlefield awareness. It wasn’t techno-detail for its sake alone.

Most other sci-fi of the era focused on various technological developments, and the characters served to showcase the doo-dad. As much as I love Asimov’s robot stories, the humans exist mostly to explain and show off his robots. In his Foundation series, people exist mainly to showcase Hari Seldon’s psychohistory. And they’re genuinely fascinating ideas!

But Heinlein focused on how those ideas affected people.

Furthermore, his “juveniles” were not like kids stories of the era either. They featured juvenile protagonists, sure, but they dealt with adult problems. Heinlein treated children like adults-in-training, and didn’t talk down to them in his works intended for them. The only real difference I can find between his adult works and his juveniles is the protagonists age and no sex.

Of course, it should be fairly obvious at this point that Heinlein is my favorite author.

Original question-Where does Robert Heinlein belong in the pantheon of science fiction writers?

Questions: Why do people who love reading, love it so much?
Answers:
Let me take two lines from a very famous book that we have all probably heard of – Harry Potter

Raindrops the size of bullets thundered on the castle windows for days on end; the lake rose, the flower beds turned into muddy streams, and Hagrid's pumpkins swelled to the size of garden sheds.

Let us assume for the sake of this argument that I haven’t come across these lines ever in my life. When I begin to read this paragraph, the following things take place in my head almost simultaneously:
First, I envision a huge castle. Something along the lines of this –

This seems sufficiently large in my head without being overwhelmingly huge or something so minuscule it would resemble a hut rather than a castle. It is of a form and shape factor I like and this is the image I would sketch in my mind.

BOOM, my mind darts inside the castle. I am looking out from inside the castle window, my nose pressed against the glass. All I see is droplets of water. All I hear is the sound of thunder cutting through the silence like a knife. I dart outside to see the castle, but now with rain all over -

The lakes swelled and the flower beds turned into muddy streams. So the castle seems to be at the side of a lake. Add some stormy skies to the picture et voila!



Cue to the inside of the castle once again, where I see a muddy garden in front of me -


Filled with huge pumpkins!




The dog gives some perspective and merit to the enormity of my poorly photo-shopped pumpkins.

The point I am trying to make from my poorly shopped work is that a mere two sentences is capable of generating such vivid imagery in my mind. Television and movies are bound by various limitations; the primary of which is constraint of time. When you read books, you are truly transported to another world, and the only constraint is the constraint of your imagination. A book can be compared to a blank coloring book, which your mind fills in! You construct the world the way YOU want it. The scene will have a thunderstorm, a castle and a lake. But my thunderstorm, castle and lake will likely be infinitely different from yours. This is one of the reasons I hate watching TV/movie adaptations of books before reading them. When you watch a movie or a TV show every single thing ranging broadly from the characters and the locations to the small little things like the walking style of a certain character is imprinted in your mind. So when you read the book, the movie will play in your mind. If you do the opposite though, you first form your own universe when you read a book, and then compare it to the universe thought up by the producers. Isn't that so much better?

By reading books you can be Superman rescuing Lois Lane from danger, Sherlock Holmes solving a crime on a cold winter night, or Gatsby throwing an elaborate dinner party in his mansion! Like I said, the only constraint is the constraint of your imagination (and the contents of the book of-course You could not possibly put Romeo and Juliet in the picturesque setting of Mordor. Well you COULD, but it would be highly counterproductive. )

I love reading. I love imagining. It’s addictive as hell.

Questions: What is the best thing you read today?
Answers:
He Scored only an average mark of 750 in his 12th Board Exam. But he was awarded as a ‘Young Scientist’ by NASA! (These Headings in the News paper attracts me towards the best read today)

World’s lightest and smallest Satellite.

Mohammed Rifath Sharukh, a 17 year old young scientist made the World’s Lightest and Smallest Satellite!
Pallapatti born, Karur district; Tamilnadu.
NASA organised a competition. Over 8000 students from 57 countries participated. He was the only Indian who was selected among the 80 final selections.

About his Satellite:

He named the Satellite ‘ KALAM SAT’ in memory of Dr. A.P.J. Abdul kalam.
It weighs only 64 grams.(0.1 kg and 3.8 cm in size)
“Space Kidz India” supported him.
It was a complete Indian made Satellite.
Uses:
It will be used to detect the radiation in Space, and the changes in the atmosphere.
It will stay only 240 minutes in space, then it will automatically fall in to the specified ocean. Finally, it will be taken out for research.
Launch:
On June 22nd, 2017 it will be launched through the SRK Rocket.
If they launch successfully, then it will be used for Agriculture and Weather Monitoring.
I wondered when I saw Mohammed Sharukh’s 12th Board Exam Mark Details:
In Mathematics: 92/200.
In Physics: 89/200(Practical Mark: 50)

(For the rest, he wrote only for 39 marks in theory! (Less than my marks!))

He is one of the inspirations to the Students, who scored average marks in their Board Exams.
For Parents: Marks don’t determine your Children, who they are. Every Child is born with talents.

This will be the first time Indian student’s experiment will be flown by NASA. (Really appreciable!)

Questions: What is the most life changing book you've ever read?
Answers:
I don’t write in “self improvement” topic, but there is a first for everything. Two of my favorite books that I read together are: “How to get whatever you want” and “Think and Grow Rich”. I read these as a 17 year old and they were phenomenal. I tried to apply a lot of it during that time and had quite a bit of fortune implementing them. How to Get Whatever You Want
 and Think and Grow Rich
.

The key concepts like “just show up” and “just ask” —are so simple and yet so powerful.

I will give you examples of how I used it.

I was in my second year of college when we had the annual programming contest to select the top team to go to the prestigious ACM ICPC. I was preparing for the contest since the time I joined college. I led a team that was short of 1 person [he had to leave another contest in the last minute] and we tied up for the top slot. The other team were one year senior to us and the college gave them the slot to go to the Asia regionals in IIT Kanpur. I didn’t like the idea of seniority just used to break the tie.

I would have given up if not for that crazy book above. I just explored for sometime the other alternatives in the days before social media and found an Asia regionals happened in Dhaka, Bangladesh. I just found out the organiser’s number and called him out of the blue [when it cost over $1/min for the international call from a public booth and I had very little money]. I convinced him to take our team from India. I went through all the rules and he could not find any hole in my argument. He was more amused by the strange request from a teenager from abroad and okayed my proposal.

And then came the task of convincing my teammates that Bangladesh was a safe country to go to. We had a trip of our lifetimes taking a 3.5 day travel one way from the southern part of India to Bangladesh over 2 trains and a bus. It was an amazing experience interacting with everyone there and although we could not make it to the world finals we got home with a honorable mention for being in the top 10%. I should have tried the following 2 years too, but somehow never participated [and of course I regret that now for not showing up].

From sitting in a small town in the middle of nowhere in a day without all the information revolution to getting there was a big win for me.

Two months later I did an even crazier thing. I was in New Delhi attending a college competition. I got a strange idea to walk up to the Rashtrapati Bhavan [President’s palace] to get a meeting with the President of the largest democracy. In an another time I would not have done that, but I was crazy in the power of asking. It could not harm, right?

I just showed up and asked. The secretary thought it was funny that a teenager was walking up to get an appointment with the President of India. She still passed up my request to President’s PA. A day later my relative got the call that the President wanted to talk to me. He was genuinely curious about a teenager who came all the way from the southern part of India and had gumption to write to him.

That led to the greatest day in my life: Why is Abdul Kalam widely loved and respected by everyone? — where I got a 40 minute one-on-one with the President and got another such meeting just 6 months later.

A year later I was applying for grad school. I got an admission, but without a scholarship. I called up a professor and explained the situation. He not only gave the scholarship that enabled me to go to gradschool, but someone who is still in touch with me after so many year.

I applied the same principles to a lot of smaller successes too — from getting airline seats upgraded to getting into contests. Once I was in Linuxcon where there was a Linux quiz & raffle. I answered the quiz and they asked us to come for a raffle in the afternoon. I usually don’t go for this and thought there will be a big crowd. When I showed up there was just 1 other guy and I had a 50% chance of winning. And winning I did of a good laptop that I immediately sold on eBay. All I had to do was just show up. Another time I saw a startup competition going on. I was in for an another event and asked if I could pitch. The qualifiers were already over a long time ago, but they still let me pitch in the finals. I strangely won the pitch prize for someone who knew about the contest only 30 min before.

After I graduated from college, I failed to use many of the principles as I grew to think that “self improvement” stuff is just icky. That means that I also went back to my old ways of being too shy to ask for stuff and thus went on a period of plateau with no major success in life. Now putting those principles back to motion. If you aim for the right thing, be reasonable, persistent and show up everytime you could very likely get that thing.

We often think of success as a cut throat race where you race against thousands. Often what I found was success was a race where only a handful even show up — others are either lazy, unaware or too shy to even ask to get in. Winning often happen in contests that most don’t even know exists.

Questions: Is it important in Judaism to read the Talmud from start to finish in the same manner you would read a series of books (Harry Potter for example), or can you just pick and choose which sections to read?
Answers:
You don’t “read” Talmud- that’s not what you do with it! Talmud is studied actively- it is acted out, discussed and debate. Sitting and reading it like Harry Potter sounds like the most soul-achingly boring, pointless, meaningless activity I can imagine without making a bit of an effort.

Imagine reading the instruction manual of a washing machine rather than actively using it to make the machine work- that’s an analogy for just reading the Talmud like a book.

The Talmud is dense. It is actively studied page by page, with all the commentary and hypertext included. It is dissected, discussed, debated- that’s Talmud.

İt’s not important where you start. Although it is common to work your way through systematically in study sessions, you can jump in anywhere- there is no logical order and it is not organised by topic so it really makes no difference.

I often get the feeling that many people have no real idea what the Talmud is. Certainly it is not a book you sit and read like a novel- that sounds terrible!

Questions: What is the last book you tried to read that was so bad you just could not finish it?
Answers:
That would be “Inferno” by Dan Brown.

Like most people, I got turned on to Dan Brown because of The DaVinci Code and followed back around to read Angels and Demons. When it came out, I read the Lost Symbol too.

I enjoyed the first two as good light reading. The third just started stretching the premise of a hero symbologist a little too far for my taste, but it wasn’t so bad that I didn’t finish it.

When Inferno came out, I bought it, hoping it would get back to the quality of at least Angels and Demons.

As the premise started to unfold, I tried to keep with it, but, my brow a bit furrowed, I turned my head to Dr. Scott, my wife, and asked for clarification…

“Isn’t Plague Bacterial” Can’t it be cured with antibiotics?”

“Of course,” she replied.

I tossed the book aside and never picked it up again.

Questions: What is the best thing you read today?
Answers:
Do you know who the man is in the photo below?

By his appearance, you must be thinking that he might be a boy from lower middle class family, working in a bakery to earn money and support his family.

But no, that's not the truth.

He is Dhravya Dholakia[1], son of a billionaire Savji Dholakia.[2]

Surat diamond magnate Savji Dholakia caught the world’s attention two years ago when he rewarded 1200 employees with apartments and cars as Diwali bonus.[3]

For teaching his son how challenging life is, he decided to ask his son Dhravya Dholakia to go to an unfamiliar place and earn livelihood through odd work.

Dhravya Dholakia(21) who is studying Business management in US, came to India on summer holidays to enjoy with family.

Dhravya Dholakia accepted his father's challenge and left for Kochi with Rs 7000, a pair of clothes and nothing else.

Condition of his challenge

First Dharvya needed to find some work but wherever he joins, he should not stay there for more than a week.
He should not use his father’s identity
He should not use those Rs 7000 until an emergency.

Dhravya accepted the challenge and went to Kochi where Hindi would not help him.

Difficulties he faced

For 5 days, Dhravya did not have any proper place to stay nor did he have any job. He was rejected from 60 places, he lied that he was from a very poor family and wanted to earn money to help his family. At last he got a job in a bakery. He kept switching jobs. Do you know how much he earned? He earned Rs 4000.

Dhravya Dholakia said

I never worried about money and here I was struggling to get a one time meal worth Rs 40 and I needed another Rs 250 per day to stay in a lodge.

What do you think? Isn't that great? Isn't it a good lesson for life?

Every father (whether from rich or middle class family) should do this experiment with his son/daughter to teach them true values of life.

Thanks

Image source :- google

Information source

https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=2136078463115177&id=120674037988973

Surat Billionaire Who Gave Big Bonuses Sent Son To Find Work In Kerala

Questions: Why are Judy Blume books so controversial?
Answers:
Judy Blume has written many good books over the years, but I’ll highlight just a few of them and the reasons for their being challenged or banned:

Are You There, God? It’s Me, Margaret

Blume’s 1970 classic centers on Margaret Simon and the ups and downs she deals with as she approaches adolescence. Among other things, she crushes on a cute boy in her class, begins wearing a bra, and, more than anything, longs to get her first period. What’s more, she has a close relationship with God (hence, the title), though she doesn’t have any religious affiliation due to her parents’ interfaith marriage and the problems they had with Margaret’s grandparents because of it. This book has been popular with girls since its publication, but it has run into problems with censorship due its focus on Margaret’s preoccupation with menstruation and sexual development, not to mention her lack of religious affiliation
. I’ve read the book myself—and own a copy—but some people just can’t handle characters who actually think about their own reproductive development and/or don’t belong to any organized religion. Oh, well.

Forever

Judy’s book focusing on the sexual relationship between its protagonists, Katherine and Michael, has drawn heat for the frank depictions of sex.
 And of course, the characters have sex more than once. The book, actually, can teach us something valuable about relationships. For me, it told me something about relationships and love—and the relationship between the two. But, like the aforementioned Margaret, some people just can’t handle sex. Sigh. . .

Blubber

Probably more than the other two books, this book hits very close to home (especially for me) due to its subject: bullying. This work from 1974 centers on the bullying of a fifth grade girl. Nicknamed Blubber because of a report she gives on whales and her weight, Linda becomes the target of a select group of girls, as well as others in her class. Told from the viewpoint of one of the bullies, Jill Brenner, Blubber shows the painful abuse Linda is subjected to. Like Are You There, God? It’s Me, Margaret and Forever. . ., Blubber also has been challenged because of the abuse Linda’s classmates inflict on her and the profanity of some of the characters
. Having been subjected to bullying as a youngster, I can understand some of the reasons for not liking this book. For that reason, I would not read it again—just too painful. But that’s no excuse for banning it. It needs to be read and in fact, it could play a role in helping to address real-life bullying.

Questions: What is the densest short book you have come across? For example, I think Machiavelli's The Prince contains more in 100 pages than many do at a thousand.
Answers:
That would be a very short book of poetry by the French poet, novelist, editor and general man of letters and numbers, Raymond Queneau.

Raymond Queneau at his usual slight angle to the rest of the universe.

Queneau (1903–1976) was perhaps best known for his 1959 novel Zazie in the Metro, which was made into a 1960 movie by Louis Malle.

The central irony of the novel is that the titular character, Zazie, spends the entire book on her first journey to Paris, in which the only thing she wants to do is travel on the Metro, but she never actually manages to—except at the end of the book, by which time she’s fallen asleep and doesn’t notice. Queneau’s original novel is a good deal more original and more strange than Malle’s irritatingly wacky movie.

Queneau wrote quite a few novels, as well as the unclassifiable 1947 Exercises in Style in which he exhaustively recounted the same trivial anecdote in 99 different ways, but I think his real genius is in his poetry. He liked popular culture, and some of his poems, such as ‘Si tu t’imagines’, became cabaret songs. He was a wonderful poet about city life: Courir les rues, available in English as Hitting the Streets, is a great, warm, life-affirming book. Not a lot of the rest of his poetry has been translated into English, unfortunately.

In 1961, he published the subject of this answer: a collection of ten sonnets entitled One Hundred Thousand Billion Poems.

If it’s only got ten poems in it, why the title?

Well, Queneau deliberately wrote it so that after reading the first line of one of the poems, you could read the second line of one of the other ones, followed by the third line of another one, etc., and it would make just as much sense, and would still rhyme.

This means that, because each poem has 14 lines, there are 
10
14
1014
 or 100,000,000,000,000 ways of reading the book. Queneau calculated that if you spent 45 seconds reading each possible sonnet and allowed 15 seconds for page turning, and you didn’t do anything else with your time but read 24 hours a day, it would take you 190,258,751 years to read every possible sonnet and, therefore, ‘finish’ the book.

Here’s the first poem laid out on the page in such a way that you can keep track of what line you’re on (photo deliberately fuzzy so as to ward off copyright issues):

Queneau thought that the reader could slit the pages so that they could form their own poems, like those kids’ books where you can assemble imaginary animals out of parts of other animals.

He was also a founding member of the great literary collective/project OuLiPo
, and is the dedicatee of one of the greatest 20th century novels, Life A User’s Manual, by his friend and fan Georges Perec.

I think any book that takes you over 190 million years to read is a strong candidate for being one of the densest books of all time. And it takes up just ten pages in his collected poems (1,699 pages, including notes and editorial material).

Thanks for reading.

Questions: Why do liberals think that sexually explicit books should be available in school libraries?
Answers:
Please tell us what’s sexually explicit in “The Diary of Anne Frank.”

Or “The Bluest Eye”

Or “Catcher in the Rye.”

But apparently THIS sexually explicit stuff is OK in school libraries;

“She did not give up the prostitution she began in Egypt, when during her youth men slept with her, caressed her virgin bosom and poured out their lust on her.” (Ezekiel 23:8)

“…she was a prostitute in Egypt. There she lusted after her lovers, whose genitals were like those of donkeys and whose emission was like that of horses. So you longed for the lewdness of your youth, when in Egypt your bosom was caressed and your young breasts fondled.’ (Ezekiel 23:20–21)

Please tell us, Conservatives, if passages like that were in ANY OTHER BOOK besides the Bible, would you demand it be banned from school?

Questions: Why was Ender so young? I liked the book, but I thought, not even wait for him to be a teenager was too much.
Answers:
I've known a few brilliant children who solemnly try to fulfill adult expectations.

Ender was put in command so young because that's when the Earthling fleet reache all the hibve queens’ planets. They would rather have trained him longer, his jeesh as well, but these children were the best overall commanders they had. I didn't show all the arguments they had after Ender was admitted to battle school as the great hope for the human species. Decisions were not unanimous. Showing the arguments would have been, pointless, because the reader would know that the book would not be called Ender's Game if he Doesn't end up in command. I don't like wasting the reader's time by showing pointless arguments whose outcome is already obvious.

Questions: Who is your favorite historical “mad lad”?
Answers:
That would be Russia’s Peter the Great. Picture, if you will, a man. He is a strapping fellow. Head full of wavy dark hair, a curly moustache like Dali or Poirot. Sharply dressed, immensely powerful and tall to the point of hitting his head repeatedly on door frames and ceilings — the Tsar stood at 6′8″ which was absolutely magnificent and quite unusual in his day and age.

Now Peter, in spite of his incredibly striking appearance, had a tendency for going undercover. He did this even before he officially assumed full power — he’d put on the clothes of a peasant, have a shave, cut or hide his glorious locks and make himself look rather filthy. He’d then mingle with the common folk in remote corners of his empire where they had never laid eyes on their ruler, and pretend to be one of them. It seems like a foolish thing to do, but apparantly it the man actually, by some miracle, pulled it off.

At some point, Peter wants to know how ships are built. He wants the very finest designs for his Russian fleet. So he looks around, asks his advisors… where do they build the finest ships? In his day and age, it was the Dutch who built the finest ships, they tell the young prince. So what does this absolute madlad do? He ditches his entourage, travels undercover to the Low Countries and… applies for a ship wharf!

Peter is shaven. His hair dyed, his clothes those of a poor man. Many immigrant workers are employed by the Dutch companies, and when they see the massive lad applying for a job, they only need to look at his 6′8″ frame once to see this fellow has ‘what it takes’. So they hire Peter. And he does the work of five men, easily. As he carries heavy pieces of wood, hammers to his heart’s content and works his fingers to the bone, he takes mental notes of everything. Where does this piece go, how is the hull shaped, where does the mast go and how thick is it? He wants to know it all. And he has an amazing, almost photogenic memory.

Young Peter works as a part of the building crew on a Dutch vessel for months. Amazingly, the huge Russian immigrant goes undetected. He slips away as easily as he slipped in, hurries home and gives his builders instructions on how to build the fine fleet he had envisioned… Like a boss!

Questions: What are the biggest lies that society tells us?
Answers:
“Don’t settle for anything less. Stick to your standards and you will finally meet that person who you deserve! You deserve nothing less than the best!”

Yeah well, I’d like to give some folks a red pill of cold reality. Because I’ve seen this story play out more times than I could care to count in the many big U.S. cities where I’ve lived.

As I like to say to both men and women when they tell me of the fantastic expectations they have of potential partners -

“Look at what you have to offer first, before you draw up your long list of expectations, let alone demands.”

You’ll see this play out time and again in large cities where you have what I like to call the “illusion of access”.

What I mean by that term is that in a city like New York, you have incredibly rich men and very beautiful women. So an inordinate number of other men and women think “Why should I settle for any less, huh?”

I’ve met women who say that “all they want” in a partner is a handsome guy who makes at least $250–300k a year, is highly educated, super smart, has a great sense of humor, can cook decently and is a great dancer.

That’s all? Wow, you REALLY need to elevate your standards lady! You left out some basic must-haves in any romantic partner like “must be a fire-eater”, “can kill a tiger while eating a sandwich with one hand” and “can sing like Pavarotti”.

Note, these aren’t women who are drop dead gorgeous neurosurgeons or theoretical physicists or something. Regular plain Janes looking high and low for that elusive Mr. Universe.

Likewise I’ve known regular guys who have beautiful loving girlfriends who will ask me “I sometimes wonder whether I could have done better?

“No you COULD NOT HAVE, you effing moron! In cold terms she is more desirable than you. By far. And she loves you. Rule #1 - When you got a good thing going, don't fuck with it.” (yeah I've actually had to say that in the past).

They’ll wait and wait for that perfect person because well I mean, look at sitcoms like Sex and the City. Shit worked out there, no? And of course we all know that TV sitcoms superbly simulate the way real life works!

Then they get to an age when they start to panic wholesale. Oh what will I do now!

Well kid, you kept waiting endlessly for that perfect person to come along and guess what? S/he did, and walked right past you.

Set your expectations realistically.

This does not mean for a moment that you jump into a relationship or marriage with the first Joe or Jane who comes around the block.

But please have a clear-headed assessment of yourself and what YOU bring to the table.

Sorry, I sound hard and cold here but it had to be said.

Because your friends in all good intention will keep telling you to stick to your guns, not lower your standards, you “deserve the best and nothing less.” Note once again that by “best” here I mean in cold objective terms like income, looks, education level etc…… not in such things as that person sincerely loving you (that one is a basic must-have).

Well no, the best things are so valued precisely because they are scarce.

You don’t go looking for a job and say

“Must not be more than 20 hours a week, ten weeks annual vacation, must pay at least five million dollars!…. I mean look at all those multi-millionaires… why should I settle for less??”

Set sensible and realistic standards, find someone who meets them and who wants to spend their life with you, and you’ll stand a much better chance of finding happiness both in love and in life.

Otherwise stick to your guns for long enough and they’re all you will have left in the end.

“Must not be more than 20 hours a week, ten weeks annual vacation, must pay at least five million dollars!…. I mean look at all those multi-millionaires… why should I settle for less??”

Otherwise stick to your guns for long enough and they’re all you will have left in the end.', 'result': {'fake': 0.0561, 'real': 0.9439}, 'status': 'success'}], 'credits_used': 7, 'credits': 1990089, 'subscription': 0, 'content': "“Don’t settle for anything less. Stick to your standards and you will finally meet that person who you deserve! You deserve nothing less than the best!”

Yeah well, I’d like to give some folks a red pill of cold reality. Because I’ve seen this story play out more times than I could care to count in the many big U.S. cities where I’ve lived.

As I like to say to both men and women when they tell me of the fantastic expectations they have of potential partners -

“Look at what you have to offer first, before you draw up your long list of expectations, let alone demands.”

You’ll see this play out time and again in large cities where you have what I like to call the “illusion of access”.

What I mean by that term is that in a city like New York, you have incredibly rich men and very beautiful women. So an inordinate number of other men and women think “Why should I settle for any less, huh?”

I’ve met women who say that “all they want” in a partner is a handsome guy who makes at least $250–300k a year, is highly educated, super smart, has a great sense of humor, can cook decently and is a great dancer.

That’s all? Wow, you REALLY need to elevate your standards lady! You left out some basic must-haves in any romantic partner like “must be a fire-eater”, “can kill a tiger while eating a sandwich with one hand” and “can sing like Pavarotti”.

Note, these aren’t women who are drop dead gorgeous neurosurgeons or theoretical physicists or something. Regular plain Janes looking high and low for that elusive Mr. Universe.

Likewise I’ve known regular guys who have beautiful loving girlfriends who will ask me “I sometimes wonder whether I could have done better?

“No you COULD NOT HAVE, you effing moron! In cold terms she is more desirable than you. By far. And she loves you. Rule #1 - When you got a good thing going, don't fuck with it.” (yeah I've actually had to say that in the past).

They’ll wait and wait for that perfect person because well I mean, look at sitcoms like Sex and the City. Shit worked out there, no? And of course we all know that TV sitcoms superbly simulate the way real life works!

Then they get to an age when they start to panic wholesale. Oh what will I do now!

Well kid, you kept waiting endlessly for that perfect person to come along and guess what? S/he did, and walked right past you.

Set your expectations realistically.

This does not mean for a moment that you jump into a relationship or marriage with the first Joe or Jane who comes around the block.

But please have a clear-headed assessment of yourself and what YOU bring to the table.

Sorry, I sound hard and cold here but it had to be said.

Because your friends in all good intention will keep telling you to stick to your guns, not lower your standards, you “deserve the best and nothing less.” Note once again that by “best” here I mean in cold objective terms like income, looks, education level etc…… not in such things as that person sincerely loving you (that one is a basic must-have).

Well no, the best things are so valued precisely because they are scarce.

You don’t go looking for a job and say

“Must not be more than 20 hours a week, ten weeks annual vacation, must pay at least five million dollars!…. I mean look at all those multi-millionaires… why should I settle for less??”

Set sensible and realistic standards, find someone who meets them and who wants to spend their life with you, and you’ll stand a much better chance of finding happiness both in love and in life.

Otherwise stick to your guns for long enough and they’re all you will have left in the end.", 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

26.11.2008 is one of the darkest days in the Indian history. Ten terrorists from the terror group Laskar-e-Taiba carried out a series of shooting and bombing attacks for four days killing 164 people and injuring over 300.

They planned for Hindu terrorism and then a book of 26/11 RSS ki Sazish and all.
Congress started the term Hindu terrorism a while ago from 26/11 attack.
I feel India’s people/party were involved in attack.

• laying down his life

• catching Kasab alive

• fighting AK 47 with a lathi.

Thank you brave man, Tukaram Omble ji.

Had it not been for him, the fake 'Hindu Atankwad' theory would have been an international reality now. Diggy was all ready with books n press conference.

He changed all the script written by Lutyens and their pet news channels in a few minutes.

May his Soul attain Moksha.

Questions: What is the best thing you read today?
Answers:
Do you know this girl?

She is Ummul Kher, AIR 420 , UPSC exams.

She has been suffering from fragile bone disorder from her birth which has made her disabled.

Being a good student she always wanted to study despite her odds. For this she needed a constant support system. And for such person who it can be better than her parents.

But unfortunately she wasn't lucky. Her parents who lived in the slums of Old Delhi didn't want to spend on her education after class 8, but she was determined to study further.

She was given two options .. Either listen to her parents or leave the house at the age of 12.

She chose the 2nd option .

Leaving everything behind, she had to leave her home and start a new life in a jhopparpatti (slum type house) without any support. To fund her school fees she used to take tuitions from 3 pm to 11 pm and earn around 50–100 rupees from the slum children. She passed her 12th with an excellent 91%.

After that she joined Gargi college and continued to fund her education through tuitions and the prize money she won through college debates.

In 2012, she met a small accident and was confined to a wheelchair for a year due to her bone disorder.

After graduation , she cracked the entrance exams of JNU for Masters of International studies. She was getting a scholarship of Rs 25000 which meant she didn't have to take tuitions. And after so much hardwork she cleared her UPSC exams under disability quota.

Despite all these sufferings she didn't have any complaint against her parents and she believed that it was the situation which forced them to take this decision..

While many of us who aren't disabled get exhausted after some hardwork and there is this girl who defied all odds and made us believe in determination and hardwork.

Where there is a will there is a way…

Respects to you ma'am...

Cheers!!!

Edit 1: My first post to cross 1k upvotes and 25k views.

Thank you very much my dear fellow quorans.

And thanks for the edits User-10009868372832024630 & Shreyance Parakh .

Edit 2: Some people are asking if the story is real or not.. So please click the below link.

Hindustan Times

Thank you..

Questions: How does the 1978 animated version of Lord Of The Rings by Ralph Bakshi hold up compared to the books and was it well liked or hated?
Answers:
I just watched it again not long ago, along with some friends, so I’ll give my thoughts.

A friend of mine hosts screenings of films quite often, including regular Friday Night Movies that I regularly attend as we are both cinephiles. When she mentioned to me that she was planning on doing The Lord of the Rings, I was quite excited, especially as there would be people present that had never seen it, and as this is an online virtual watch-party with a chatroom, I could prattle on to my heart’s content without disturbing anyone’s enjoyment of the films.

We watched the extended versions of the Peter Jackson film over a period of 3 weeks, and then for the fourth Friday of “Rings Month” we watched the Ralph Bakshi film. I can tell you that it is a very enjoyalbe film on a few levels - it is in some ways closer to the book than Peter Jackson’s film in some very specific ways, the animation is captivating and it is clearly a labor of love. It is also a gigantic mess.

Everything after Frodo leaves the shire is a hurried mess - even before that there were issues, such as Gandalf asking Frodo if he sees any writing on the ring, and then never showing the writing from the fire. Aragorn shows his broken sword in Bree, and it’s in one piece after Rivendell, but the reforging of the blade is completely skipped. Saruman’s name was considered too close to Sauron so they changed it to Aruman, but at several points they slip up and call him Saruman. Some scenes are not animated, but life action with a filter over it to make it look animated.

All of these issues were to squeeze everything from Frodo starting his quest to the victory at Helm’s Deep into a single 138 minute film. Some of the character designs are strange, especially Boromir as a Viking-esque man, Gimli being bald and whatever the hell is up with Sam’s face. And it’s unfinished with no sequel other than the TV special made out of The Return ...

Questions: Should I read the Harry Potter series considering the fact that I have already seen the movies numerous times?
Answers:
Let's see.

Do you know what color Harry's eyes really are and why they are important?
Do you know all the Weasley kids?
Do you know who Peeves is?
Do you really know and understand why Snape mistreated Neville so much? Did you even notice that Snape mistreated Neville more than others?
Do you know what an animagus is?
Do you know and understand Voldemort's history?
Do you know what happens to Peter Pettigrew in the end and why?
Do you know who are all the Marauder's?
Do you know who was the Half-Blood Prince and why he was called so?
Do you know who Squibs are?
Do you know why Rita Skeeter's character is important and where it was important?
Do you know and understand Snape's history?
Do you understand Dumbledore's character, his behavior towards Harry right from the 1st book, and what was his overall importance to the series?
Do you know the history behind Lupin and Tonks? How they ended up getting married? Do you know who Teddy is?
Do you know who Phineus Nigellus is and why he was important?
Do you know who Barty Crouch Jr. is and what his backstory is? Do you know who Winky is?
Do you know what happens to Harry's wand in the end?
Do you know why the following scene is the complete opposite of the entire series storyline?





It's quite simple.
Do you care to know about the above? I have not even skimmed half of the things you have missed out because of not reading the books.

If you have seen the movies numerous times, I would assume you liked them.

If you really did like them then I would assume you were fascinated by the story and the entire wizarding world as well.

If you were fascinated by the story and that world then I would assume you have questions regarding few things like some of the questions above.

This is the point which makes it "simple" for you.

Do not judge a book by its movie!


If you really have questions, then yes, you should read the books. You won't appreciate the story otherwise and you surely wouldn't think the movies are good enough. It's a rule of thumb for almost any scenario - The original books are better than the movie adaptations. Those questions are answered in the books. You would understand and appreciate the characters much much better than the movies.

If you don't have any questions, then you don't really care about the story, the fantasy world, the magic behind it all. You don't have to bother reading the books. But remember the following -


The above represents how much you will lose out on by not reading the books.

So it's quite simple. Read them.
